newsitem.title: UK: UK should join EMU if terms right - Labour's Bell.
newsitem.headline: UK should join EMU if terms right - Labour's Bell.

text.p: Britain is right for now to retain its opt-out from the European Union's planned single currency, but it would be wrong not to join in the first wave of countries in 1999 if the conditions are all met, a senior member of the main opposition Labour party said on Thursday.
"It is right for both opposition and government at the moment to say 'wait and see'," Stuart Bell, a spokesman on trade and corporate affairs, told a business conference.
"But if this is in our national interest -- no one can tell until next year -- then we must go forward," he said.
Labour, like the ruling Conservative party, has agreed to put any cabinet decision to join the single currency to a referendum, which Bell said would be a "historic decision".
Britain holds the rotating six-month EU presidency in the first half of 1998 when the final decision will be taken on which countries will be eligible to join the single currency.

"And if we are able to meet the convergence criteria and then we say to the Europeans we meet the criteria but we are not going to join' that is a very odd position for a trading nation which has 57 percent of its exports going into Europe," Bell said.
He said there was no point in Britain saying it would join a single currency but only as part of a later, second wave of countries.
"If we are not in on the first wave we'll lose all influence on the European Central Bank. We'll have no executive sitting on that bank," he said.
If economic and monetary union did go ahead without Britain, Bell said sterling would have to contend with three global currencies -- the dollar, the euro, yen and sterling.
"And where would we be on that basis?" he asked. "Our only long-term future is to create stability for our currency so our exporters have certainty in the future," he said.
